content.raw:
Is `AdvertiseOptions` not available outside of the publisher? Is that why we're assuming that we won't record it?

It seems that the only field in `AdvertiseOptions` right now is the scope, which probably won't impact playback in any significant way (I think we can make the default playback scope be `ALL`, and it wouldn't affect anything negatively).

That said, if we ever extend `AdvertiseOptions` to contain fields that could affect the fidelity of a playback, we might want to consider ways to broadcast those settings, perhaps over a meta-topic.
content.html:
Is AdvertiseOptions not available outside of the publisher? Is that why we're assuming that we won't record it?

It seems that the only field in AdvertiseOptions right now is the scope, which probably won't impact playback in any significant way (I think we can make the default playback scope be ALL, and it wouldn't affect anything negatively).

That said, if we ever extend AdvertiseOptions to contain fields that could affect the fidelity of a playback, we might want to consider ways to broadcast those settings, perhaps over a meta-topic.

content.raw: Yeah, I'm assuming it is not available outside of the publisher.
content.html: Yeah, I'm assuming it is not available outside of the publisher.

content.raw: Should this be `NOT NULL`?
content.html: Should this be NOT NULL?

content.raw: I'm not sure. How do we get access to the protobuf file? Rosbag can get the .msg file in ros1 because the whole thing is sent by the publisher when a publisher and the rosbag subscriber connect. That doesn't seem to be a part of the process in ignition transport.

content.raw: @caguero and I have discussed sending a mechanism to retrieve protobuf descriptors via topics or services. Looks like logging is another use case for this (in addition to topic echo).
content.html: @caguero and I have discussed sending a mechanism to retrieve protobuf descriptors via topics or services. Looks like logging is another use case for this (in addition to topic echo).

content.raw: Agreed, @sloretz , is not possible at this moment.
content.html: Agreed, @sloretz , is not possible at this moment.

content.raw:
I'm still wrapping up my investigation, but I don't think we'll need to store the descriptors for the logging to work exactly as we want it to. If my understanding is correct, protobuf can reconstruct the messages without any difficulty, even without the message description available. The only catch is that if a user doesn't have access to a compatible version of the message description, then they'll have to use protobuf's Reflection interface to actually use the deserialized message.

The only benefit we'd get from storing the message description files would be that we could (in theory) extract the description information from the log and regenerate the message source code in some kind of pre-processing step. Essentially, we'd be enabling the user of a log to install the message types out of the log file. I'm not sure how important that hypothetical feature really is.
content.html:
I'm still wrapping up my investigation, but I don't think we'll need to store the descriptors for the logging to work exactly as we want it to. If my understanding is correct, protobuf can reconstruct the messages without any difficulty, even without the message description available. The only catch is that if a user doesn't have access to a compatible version of the message description, then they'll have to use protobuf's Reflection interface to actually use the deserialized message.

The only benefit we'd get from storing the message description files would be that we could (in theory) extract the description information from the log and regenerate the message source code in some kind of pre-processing step. Essentially, we'd be enabling the user of a log to install the message types out of the log file. I'm not sure how important that hypothetical feature really is.

content.raw: I didn't think protobuf could deserialize a string into an unknown message type. Is there a function that can take a serialized string and spit out a message without a descriptor or strongly typed message?
content.html: I didn't think protobuf could deserialize a string into an unknown message type. Is there a function that can take a serialized string and spit out a message without a descriptor or strongly typed message?

content.raw:
That seems to be the role of the [DynamicMessageFactory](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/reference/cpp/google.protobuf.dynamic_message). I believe if we pass a blank [Descriptor](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/reference/cpp/google.protobuf.descriptor#Descriptor) object to `DynamicMessageFactory::GetPrototype(~)`, it should construct a completely generic message which we can then operate on using the [Reflection](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/reference/cpp/google.protobuf.message#Reflection) interface (although we'll only be able to do operations based on the field indices; we don't be able to do anything that uses the field names).

I'm still in the process of getting 100% confirmation on this, but it's looking very promising. I plan on putting together a test of my findings very soon.
content.html:
That seems to be the role of the DynamicMessageFactory. I believe if we pass a blank Descriptor object to DynamicMessageFactory::GetPrototype(~), it should construct a completely generic message which we can then operate on using the Reflection interface (although we'll only be able to do operations based on the field indices; we don't be able to do anything that uses the field names).

I'm still in the process of getting 100% confirmation on this, but it's looking very promising. I plan on putting together a test of my findings very soon.

content.raw:
Interesting option.

We plan on supporting acquisition of message descriptors via ign-transport. It seems like a lot of complexity in order to save a relatively small amount of data from being stored in the database. Also, if we don't store descriptors, we loose exact descriptions of the messages which are useful for migrations and introspection.

Maybe we could use dynamic message generation as a fallback feature, sometime in the future.
content.html:
Interesting option.

We plan on supporting acquisition of message descriptors via ign-transport. It seems like a lot of complexity in order to save a relatively small amount of data from being stored in the database. Also, if we don't store descriptors, we loose exact descriptions of the messages which are useful for migrations and introspection.

Maybe we could use dynamic message generation as a fallback feature, sometime in the future.

content.raw:
Just to clarify, `ign-transport` is already using the dynamic message generation as a special case when someone subscribes to a topic with a callback that expects a generic `google::protobuf::Message` type. We could actually move forward with this descriptorless approach as-is without any complexity or changes to `ign-transport`.

Storing the descriptions could certainly make migration between message types safer, although if "good practices" are used with protobuf, then migration between message types should be trivial, because message types should always be forward and backward compatible ("good practices" in this case means you never reuse a field index when changing the description, which is a reasonably simple rule to follow).

My main concern with trying to enforce the transmission and recording of descriptors is that I'm not sure how to ensure that it's possible for arbitrary message types. I think we would need a way to serialize an arbitrary `Descriptor` object, but I don't know of any built-in mechanism in protobuf for doing that. The closest thing I can think of is [self-describing messages](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/techniques#self-description), but that requires the message to be generated in a very specific way, so it's not generalizable.

I guess one straightforward option is to make all the messages in `ign-msgs` self-describing. Then for users' custom message types we just handle them as generic protobuf messages, and the user just needs to accept the consequences.
content.html:
Just to clarify, ign-transport is already using the dynamic message generation as a special case when someone subscribes to a topic with a callback that expects a generic google::protobuf::Message type. We could actually move forward with this descriptorless approach as-is without any complexity or changes to ign-transport.

Storing the descriptions could certainly make migration between message types safer, although if "good practices" are used with protobuf, then migration between message types should be trivial, because message types should always be forward and backward compatible ("good practices" in this case means you never reuse a field index when changing the description, which is a reasonably simple rule to follow).

My main concern with trying to enforce the transmission and recording of descriptors is that I'm not sure how to ensure that it's possible for arbitrary message types. I think we would need a way to serialize an arbitrary Descriptor object, but I don't know of any built-in mechanism in protobuf for doing that. The closest thing I can think of is self-describing messages, but that requires the message to be generated in a very specific way, so it's not generalizable.

I guess one straightforward option is to make all the messages in ign-msgs self-describing. Then for users' custom message types we just handle them as generic protobuf messages, and the user just needs to accept the consequences.

content.raw:
Use of a generic message is painful, and I would like to avoid it. Quoting the protobuf docs: "given only a raw message without the corresponding .proto file defining its type, it is difficult to extract any useful data". My understanding is that with a raw message, a user would have to either know what fields are there, or search the message for fields that interest them.

This is really a usability issue. We could require that all users of logging have intimate knowledge of protobuf's API, but we should avoid this if possible.

If we can create a self-describing message, then we should be able to store that self describing message (or the necessary bits) in the database, correct?
content.html:
Use of a generic message is painful, and I would like to avoid it. Quoting the protobuf docs: "given only a raw message without the corresponding .proto file defining its type, it is difficult to extract any useful data". My understanding is that with a raw message, a user would have to either know what fields are there, or search the message for fields that interest them.

This is really a usability issue. We could require that all users of logging have intimate knowledge of protobuf's API, but we should avoid this if possible.

If we can create a self-describing message, then we should be able to store that self describing message (or the necessary bits) in the database, correct?

content.raw:
For sure, I would never want to burden a user with needing to use the protobuf Reflection interface. Even worse, they'd have to use the [UnknownFieldSet](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/reference/cpp/google.protobuf.unknown_field_set#UnknownFieldSet) interface, so they wouldn't be able to look up fields by name (they could only use indices).

However, one potential use of supporting generic messages is we could create a log inspection tool (either GUI or CLI) that can present the message data to the user in a clean format, even if the message type is unknown. But our first milestone is log playback, so we can shelf this idea until playback is finished.

And yes, if we generate self-describing messages, we can store those in the database as if they were any other kind of protobuf message, but they'd have the added advantage of being fully recreatable by consumers of the log, even without access to the original `.proto` descriptor file. The one detail that I'm a bit concerned about is how this would impact message sizes, and whether it's worth the inflation of resource usage. As I understand it, the descriptor would be getting serialized over and over again with each message, and there doesn't seem to be an obvious way to separate the descriptor from the message that it describes.

All that being said, if we tweak `ign-transport` to support Publishing and Subscribing to serialized data, we can very easily achieve perfect playback without the logger or the playback node having any knowledge whatsoever of the original message descriptors. The burden of knowing the message type descriptors would fall on the nodes that are listening to the log playback, but the listening nodes need to have access to the message type in order to subscribe to the topic anyhow, so that shouldn't typically be an issue.

The only problem that would arise is if a message type has changed since the time that a log was recorded. In that case, a node that listens to the playback would need to compile against the version of the library that generated the message. Using a self-describing message or storing the descriptors in the log wouldn't really change that fact, unless the listening node wants to operate on the self-describing message using the Reflection interface.
content.html:
For sure, I would never want to burden a user with needing to use the protobuf Reflection interface. Even worse, they'd have to use the UnknownFieldSet interface, so they wouldn't be able to look up fields by name (they could only use indices).

However, one potential use of supporting generic messages is we could create a log inspection tool (either GUI or CLI) that can present the message data to the user in a clean format, even if the message type is unknown. But our first milestone is log playback, so we can shelf this idea until playback is finished.

And yes, if we generate self-describing messages, we can store those in the database as if they were any other kind of protobuf message, but they'd have the added advantage of being fully recreatable by consumers of the log, even without access to the original .proto descriptor file. The one detail that I'm a bit concerned about is how this would impact message sizes, and whether it's worth the inflation of resource usage. As I understand it, the descriptor would be getting serialized over and over again with each message, and there doesn't seem to be an obvious way to separate the descriptor from the message that it describes.

All that being said, if we tweak ign-transport to support Publishing and Subscribing to serialized data, we can very easily achieve perfect playback without the logger or the playback node having any knowledge whatsoever of the original message descriptors. The burden of knowing the message type descriptors would fall on the nodes that are listening to the log playback, but the listening nodes need to have access to the message type in order to subscribe to the topic anyhow, so that shouldn't typically be an issue.

The only problem that would arise is if a message type has changed since the time that a log was recorded. In that case, a node that listens to the playback would need to compile against the version of the library that generated the message. Using a self-describing message or storing the descriptors in the log wouldn't really change that fact, unless the listening node wants to operate on the self-describing message using the Reflection interface.

content.raw: That would be awesome to know. I always thought as Nate, that we would need the original message descriptor.
content.html: That would be awesome to know. I always thought as Nate, that we would need the original message descriptor.

content.raw: This is  a unix timestamp, correct?
content.html: This is a unix timestamp, correct?

content.raw: Correct
content.html: Correct

content.raw: The default unix timestamp has a resolution of seconds. We will need something with more resolution. We could have two fields, one for seconds since 1970 and one that contains nanoseconds.
content.html: The default unix timestamp has a resolution of seconds. We will need something with more resolution. We could have two fields, one for seconds since 1970 and one that contains nanoseconds.

content.raw: As in, Add column `time_recv_nano REAL NOT NULL`?
content.html: As in, Add column time_recv_nano REAL NOT NULL?

content.raw:
Yes, add a column, but the data type can be INTEGER. Also, I think by definition a unix timestamp is UTC. So the two columns can be:

`time_recv_sec` and `time_recv_nano`
content.html:
Yes, add a column, but the data type can be INTEGER. Also, I think by definition a unix timestamp is UTC. So the two columns can be:

time_recv_sec and time_recv_nano

content.html: b2b1d0f

content.raw: Just to confirm. The topic doesn't contain the `partition`, right? The partition name is prefixed to a topic using `@` as delimiters. For example, the real topic name that flights over the network is `@my_partition@/car/roof/scan`. The partition is removed when the message is delivered to the subscriber.
content.html: Just to confirm. The topic doesn't contain the partition, right? The partition name is prefixed to a topic using @ as delimiters. For example, the real topic name that flights over the network is @my_partition@/car/roof/scan. The partition is removed when the message is delivered to the subscriber.

content.raw: I think we  should record the partition. This would be a more accurate representation of what was logged.
content.html: I think we should record the partition. This would be a more accurate representation of what was logged.

content.raw: I had no idea that partitions existed. Should it contain the partition?
content.html: I had no idea that partitions existed. Should it contain the partition?

content.raw: The partition is something that is set at the Node level and only nodes with the same partition names can talk each other. It's possible to set it programatically when you create the node or via an environment variable. Other than that, is handled privately. We can save somewhere (probably one time, not at a topic level) the partition that we're using when launching the logger and is being used for receiving the messages (for debugging purposes maybe). However, for playingback the log, we might use a different partition, or maybe just the default one instead of the one used to capture the log. This will be more flexible.
content.html: The partition is something that is set at the Node level and only nodes with the same partition names can talk each other. It's possible to set it programatically when you create the node or via an environment variable. Other than that, is handled privately. We can save somewhere (probably one time, not at a topic level) the partition that we're using when launching the logger and is being used for receiving the messages (for debugging purposes maybe). However, for playingback the log, we might use a different partition, or maybe just the default one instead of the one used to capture the log. This will be more flexible.

content.raw: Is partition something that's set via an environment variable? Seems like logging could get away with being ignorant of it by requiring user to configure the partition correctly.
content.html: Is partition something that's set via an environment variable? Seems like logging could get away with being ignorant of it by requiring user to configure the partition correctly.

content.raw: Is possible, `IGN_PARTITION`.
content.html: Is possible, IGN_PARTITION.

content.raw: Do you suggest any way of testing the schema?
content.html: Do you suggest any way of testing the schema?

content.raw:
Automated or manually?

Use the sqlite3 command line tool for a manual check. If `.read` doesn't print an error then the SQL syntax is correct.

```
$ sqlite3 /tmp/test.db
SQLite version 3.11.0 2016-02-15 17:29:24
Enter ".help" for usage hints.
sqlite> .read tools/record/schema/0.1.0.sql

sqlite> .tables
message_types  messages       migrations     topics       
sqlite> .headers on
sqlite> .mode column
sqlite> select * from migrations;
id          from_version  to_version  time_utc           
----------  ------------  ----------  -------------------
1                         0.1.0       2017-12-11 16:22:21
sqlite> 
```

An automated test can be covered by a test for the record tool. Record will need to use the schema when creating a new database.

sqlite> select * from migrations;

----------  ------------  ----------  -------------------
1                         0.1.0       2017-12-11 16:22:21
sqlite>

An automated test can be covered by a test for the record tool. Record will need to use the schema when creating a new database.
